qas.question: What is the other name for the street trams?
Where is third rail situated in the street trams system?
What area in US discontinued using overhead wires for streetcars in 1962?
What external and weather factors can effect conduit slot?
What are the main reasons the conduit lines were converted to overhead  wire system?
All street trams use conduit what?
What is accessed through a wide slot in the road?
In what neighborhood in New York have the abandoned tracks not been paved over?
An advantage of conduit collection is much high what?
Cars on all lines have been converted to overhead wire in what city?

context: Some street trams (<a0_0>streetcars<a0_0/>) used conduit <b5_0>third-rail current collection<b5_0/>. The third rail was <a1_0>below street level<a1_0/>. The tram picked up the current through <b6_0>a plough<b6_0/> (U.S. "plow") accessed through a narrow slot in the road. In the United States, much (though not all) of the former streetcar system in <a2_0>Washington, D.C.<a2_0/> (discontinued in 1962) was operated in this manner to avoid the unsightly wires and poles associated with electric traction. The same was true with Manhattan's former streetcar system. The evidence of this mode of running can still be seen on the track down the slope on the northern access to the abandoned Kingsway Tramway Subway in central London, United Kingdom, where the slot between the running rails is clearly visible, and on P and Q Streets west of Wisconsin Avenue in the <b7_0>Georgetown<b7_0/> neighborhood of Washington DC, where the abandoned tracks have not been paved over. The slot can easily be confused with the similar looking slot for cable trams/cars (in some cases, the conduit slot was originally a cable slot). The disadvantage of conduit collection included much higher <b8_0>initial installation costs<b8_0/>, higher maintenance costs, and problems with <a3_0>leaves and snow<a3_0/> getting in the slot. For this reason, in <b9_0>Washington, D.C.<b9_0/> cars on some lines converted to overhead wire on leaving the city center, a worker in a "plough pit" disconnecting the plough while another raised the trolley pole (hitherto hooked down to the roof) to the overhead wire. In New York City for the same reasons of <a4_0>cost and operating efficiency<a4_0/> outside of Manhattan overhead wire was used. A similar system of changeover from conduit to overhead wire was also used on the London tramways, notably on the southern side; a typical changeover point was at Norwood, where the conduit snaked sideways from between the running rails, to provide a park for detached shoes or ploughs.
